text:
How can one create a LaTeX table out of a DataFrame?
Latexify.jl gives somehow more a markdown like table

elements.text:
How can one create a LaTeX table out of a DataFrame?

text:
I have not touched that part of lateixfy in years, but might

```latexify(df; env=:table)```
work?

work?

text: hmm, that does not look like a latexify thing though. Are you perhaps calling `display`  or something on the output? This looks like a display issue.

display
or something on the output? This looks like a display issue.

text: I've updated my version of Latexify and waiting for precompilation now :smile: Will let you know.

Will let you know.

display

text: Updated to latest version worked. Thanks a lot

elements.text: Updated to latest version worked. Thanks a lot

text: sure, let me know.  This part of latexify.jl has been untouched for years though, so an update should make no difference.

elements.text: sure, let me know.  This part of latexify.jl has been untouched for years though, so an update should make no difference.

text: Strange one - glad that it worked though!

elements.text: Strange one - glad that it worked though!

text: And LaTeXString comes from LaTeXStrings.jl.

elements.text: And LaTeXString comes from LaTeXStrings.jl.

text:
One smaller thing if you're a professional Latexify user :smile: Do you know how to automatically disable
`c_123` to `c_{123}` I would like to have the underscore as an actual text element. But I can probably use some replace functionality if there is no way

elements.text: One smaller thing if you're a professional Latexify user
Do you know how to automatically disable
to
I would like to have the underscore as an actual text element. But I can probably use some replace functionality if there is no way

text: in general the string column is now in math mode which seems strange

elements.text: in general the string column is now in math mode which seems strange

text: there's no way right now. Just leaving the underscores as-is would lead to strangeness since it'd make only one character a subscript. You'd need to escape the underscore.

elements.text: there's no way right now. Just leaving the underscores as-is would lead to strangeness since it'd make only one character a subscript. You'd need to escape the underscore.

text: that should really just configurable as a kwarg or something. I'll have to sort that out!

elements.text: that should really just configurable as a kwarg or something. I'll have to sort that out!

text: Thanks for your help

elements.text: Thanks for your help

text: no problems :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: no problems

text: oh... since you were talking about tables then you might be looking for `latex = false`....

elements.text: oh... since you were talking about tables then you might be looking for
latex = false

text: You can't tune how underscores are dealt with in equations but you can tell latexify not to treat table elements like maths at all.

elements.text: You can't tune how underscores are dealt with in equations but you can tell latexify not to treat table elements like maths at all.

text: latexify with latex=false that's a bit ironic :smile:

elements.text: latexify with latex=false that's a bit ironic

text: :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:
but yeah that works. The integer columns are now also text though so it doesn't really matter much I think.

elements.text: but yeah that works. The integer columns are now also text though so it doesn't really matter much I think.

text: epecially when it outputs a markdown table by default :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: epecially when it outputs a markdown table by default

text: Will need to do some postprocessing

elements.text: Will need to do some postprocessing

text:
a hack for your numbers would be to use the `fmt` kwarg. I never really intended it for this purpouse but it'll  work:

```latexify(df; env=:table, latex=false, fmt = x->"\$$x\$")```

elements.text: a hack for your numbers would be to use the
fmt
kwarg. I never really intended it for this purpouse but it'll  work:
latexify(df; env=:table, latex=false, fmt = x->"\$$x\$")

text:
I just wanted to give you a thanks Niklas for writing Latexify.jl. I've used it a lot.

And to stay slightly on topic, I often just generated the latex table from latexify, and then `replace()`  whatever caused problems during the compilations. Not the cleanest, but makes it easy to get stuff working quickly, even for relatively complex latex tables.

elements.text:
I just wanted to give you a thanks Niklas for writing Latexify.jl. I've used it a lot.

And to stay slightly on topic, I often just generated the latex table from latexify, and then
replace()
whatever caused problems during the compilations. Not the cleanest, but makes it easy to get stuff working quickly, even for relatively complex latex tables.

text: Thanks, also feel free to open issues when you encounter friction. I seldom deal with tables myself when I do my work (I'm an equation guy!) so I don't notice when something is sub-optimal.

elements.text: Thanks, also feel free to open issues when you encounter friction. I seldom deal with tables myself when I do my work (I'm an equation guy!) so I don't notice when something is sub-optimal.

text: ah fmt is nice, but gets used for every column, right?

elements.text: ah fmt is nice, but gets used for every column, right?

text: yeah, its a bit of a sledge hammer. Only applies to numbers though.

elements.text: yeah, its a bit of a sledge hammer. Only applies to numbers though.

text: oh so fmt is only for number columns? Then it's what I need. Thanks works

elements.text: oh so fmt is only for number columns? Then it's what I need. Thanks works
